href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324010930-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0030"><p id="fspara0030"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. Electrochemical tests for rate capability evaluation at room temperature (25&nbsp;°C); (a) and (b) CV curves at various scan rates after the formation, (c) and (d) linear relationship between the current peaks and the square root scan rates, (e) Na<sup>+</sup> ion diffusion coefficient at each peak, and (f) linear relationship between the log (I<sub>p</sub>) and log (scan rate) of the NM and NWO5@NM.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0145">In <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig5" name="bfig5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>f, the intercept of the linear graph represents <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-12-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>log</mi><mspace width=&quot;0.25em&quot; is=&quot;true&quot; /><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>a</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="5.169ex" height="2.548ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 2225.7 1096.9" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.697ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6C"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6F" x="278" y="0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-67" x="779" y="0"></use></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1696,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-61"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">log</mi><mspace width="0.25em" is="true"></mspace><mi is="true">a</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-12"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">log</mi><mspace width="0.25em" is="true"></mspace><mi is="true">a</mi></mrow></math></script></span>, and the slope corresponds to the <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-13-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>b</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="0.998ex" height="1.971ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 429.5 848.5" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-62"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">b</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-13"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">b</mi></mrow></math></script></span> value, with each value summarized in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S4</span></span></a>. The <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-14-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>b</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="0.998ex" height="1.971ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 429.5 848.5" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-62"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">b</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-14"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">b</mi></mrow></math></script></span> value ranges 0.5 to 1.0, where a value closer to 1 indicates a higher contribution of capacitive current. At the O1 and O2 peaks, NM had <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-15-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>b</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="0.998ex" height="1.971ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 429.5 848.5" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-62"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">b</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-15"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">b</mi></mrow></math></script></span> values of 0.786 and 0.773, respectively, while the NWO5@NM had <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-16-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>b</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="0.998ex" height="1.971ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 429.5 848.5" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-62"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">b</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-16"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">b</mi></mrow></math></script></span> values of 0.642 and 0.805, all greater than 0.5, confirming the contribution of capacitive current. This result further demonstrated that the NWO5@NM exhibited superior performance above 3.5&nbsp;V, where the O2 peak appeared, due to the capacitive current. The introduction of Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> was expected to be more effective at higher voltages.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0150">Cycling tests were conducted in low-temperature operating conditions that restrict ion diffusion. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S6</span></span></a> illustrates the discharge capacities at various current densities at 0 and −25&nbsp;°C, demonstrating the overall superior performance of the NWO5@NM. This paved the way for the introduction of GITT technology, which allows the Na<sup>+</sup> ion diffusion to be studied under various operating conditions. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7</span></span></a> presents the GITT experimental results obtained at 25, 0, and −25&nbsp;°C, while <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig6" name="bfig6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a> and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S8</span></span></a> showcase the Na<sup>+</sup> ion diffusion coefficients derived from these results. The diffusion coefficient values were calculated using a simplified equation based on Fick's second law, which has been validated by the linear relationship between voltage and τ<sup>1/2</sup> observed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. S9, S10, and S11</span></span></a> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib43" name="bbib43" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib43"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">43</span></span></a>].<span class="display"><span id="fd3" class="formula"><span class="label">(3)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-17-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math is=&quot;true&quot; /><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo stretchy=&quot;true&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>(</mo><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3C4;</mi><mo style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="42.527ex" height="5.086ex" viewBox="0 -1442.7 18310.2 2189.9" role="img" height="2.317ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 1427 997.6" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" is="true">V</mi><mi is="true">M</mi></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-22"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">V</mi><mi is="true">M</mi></msub></mrow></math></script></span> is the molar volume of the electrode (24.17&nbsp;cm<sup>3</sup>·mol<sup>−1</sup>), <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-23-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-394"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(833,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-45"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(738,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3C4"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Δ</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">τ</mi></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-23"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Δ</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">τ</mi></msub></mrow></math></script></span> and <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-24-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x394;</mo><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>E</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>S</mi></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="4.943ex" height="2.432ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 2128.4 1047.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-394"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(833,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-45"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(738,-155)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-53"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Δ</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">S</mi></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-24"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Δ</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">S</mi></msub></mrow></math></script></span> are the voltage changes during the constant current flux and rest time, respectively, and <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-25-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>L</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.583ex" height="1.971ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 681.5 848.5" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-4C"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">L</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-25"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">L</mi></mrow></math></script></span> is the thickness of the electrode (cm). The calculated average Na<sup>+</sup> ion diffusion coefficients, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S5</span></span></a>, unequivocally demonstrated the superior ion diffusivity of the NWO5@NM under all conditions. Compared to the pristine NM, the NWO5@NM exhibited an approximately 46.5 % increase in diffusion coefficient at 25&nbsp;°C, 68.2 % at 0&nbsp;°C, and 253 % at −25&nbsp;°C, with the rate of increase becoming more pronounced at lower temperatures. The suppression of ion diffusion at low operating temperatures further emphasized the role of Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> as an ion diffusion channel at the grain boundaries. Consequently, GITT analysis also confirmed the significant enhancement in rate capability of the NWO5@NM.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig6"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324010930-gr6.jpg" height="502" alt="Fig. 6" aria-describedby="cap0035"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324010930-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (740KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (740KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324010930-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0035"><p id="fspara0035"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. Na<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;ion diffusion coefficients calculated from the GITT after the formation of the NM and NWO5@NM at (a) and (b) 25&nbsp;°C, (c) and (d) −25&nbsp;°C.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0155"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig7" name="bfig7" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig7"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>a shows the results of the cycling test at 1C for 100 cycles, with an additional 3 cycles at 0.1C to confirm the capacity retention. The first 3 cycles at 0.1C still indicated that the pristine NM had a higher initial discharge capacity. However, similar to previous findings, it also showed a more rapid decrease in capacity. At 1C, the first discharge capacities of NM and NWO5@NM were 128.6 and 160.8 mAh·g<sup>−1</sup>, respectively, decreasing to 82.17 and 105.5 mAh·g<sup>−1</sup>&nbsp;by the 100th cycle. Both samples showed a continuous decline in discharge capacity throughout the test, with similar slopes in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig7" name="bfig7" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig7"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>a. The capacity retention of the pristine NM and NWO5@NM was 63.9 and 65.6 %, respectively, with NWO5@NM demonstrating a comparatively better value. It was notable that the NWO5@NM consistently exhibited a higher average discharge capacity of 26.0 mAh·g<sup>−1</sup>, compared to the NM. Additionally, the discharge capacity and Coulombic efficiency data at the final 3 cycles indicated that the electrochemical reactions of the NWO5@NM were stable compared to pristine NM. The dQ/dV curves for the initial and final cycles at 0.1C, as seen in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig7" name="bfig7" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig7"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>a, are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S12</span></span></a>, providing an additional explanation. From the results of the initial 3 cycles at 0.1C, we identified the voltages at which redox reactions occurred in each sample and confirmed that the tendencies of the peaks varying with voltage for pristine NM and NWO5@NM were similar. However, during the final 3 cycles at 0.1C, the pristine NM failed to induce the initial redox reactions. Although the peaks changed for both samples after 100 cycles at 1C, NWO5@NM exhibited dQ/dV curves that were relatively similar to the initial ones. Notably, a distinct difference between the two samples was observed in the low and high-voltage regions. This is because Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> aided the charge transfer reactions of the cathode material, and still provided ion diffusion channels during cycling. The EIS results further supported this assumption.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig7"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324010930-gr7.jpg" height="547" alt="Fig. 7" aria-describedby="cap0040"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324010930-gr7_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (714KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (714KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324010930-gr7.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0040"><p id="fspara0040"><span class="label">Fig. 7</span>. (a) The capacity retention of the NM and NWO5@NM; EIS spectra of the NM and NWO5@NM (b) before, and (c) after the 100 cycles test at room temperature (25&nbsp;°C).</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0160">EIS analysis was performed on cells charged to 3.5&nbsp;V, and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig7" name="bfig7" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig7"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>b and c show the Nyquist curves before and after the cycling test at 1C. We adopted a circuit that is capable of interpreting the EIS behavior of the O3-type layered cathode. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S6</span></span></a> lists the fitting results for each sample according to the cycling test, where R0 represents the Ohmic resistance, R1 is the Na<sup>+</sup> migration resistance across the solid electrolyte interface (SEI) layer, and R2 and R3 represent the charge transfer resistance [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib44" name="bbib44" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib44"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">44</span></span></a>]. Unlike LIBs, layered cathodes for SIBs exhibit complex phase transitions during cycling [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib45" name="bbib45" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib45"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">45</span></span></a>], with the influence of O3 (or O′3) and P3 phases resulting in two intermediate frequency semicircles on the Nyquist plot. The total charge transfer resistance was obtained by adding R2 and R3. Therefore, the charge transfer resistance for the NM and NWO5@NM was 63.37 and 50.41&nbsp;Ω, respectively, before cycling, and 171.2 and 133.1&nbsp;Ω after cycling. This suggested that the Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> effectively reduced the charge transfer resistance at the grain boundaries, which served as reaction sites.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0165">Our study culminated in the use of XPS, to analyze the surface of the electrodes from the coin cells post-cycling tests. This analysis was crucial to uncovering side reactions triggered by the electrolyte during cycling. We disassembled coin cells inside an Ar-filled glove box, and washed the obtained working electrodes with dimethyl carbonate for XPS analysis. The C 1s XPS spectra, as depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig8" name="bfig8" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig8"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>a and d, revealed the emergence of C–O and C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="double bond">O peaks, indicative of side reactions involving carbonate-based electrolytes. The varying intensity of these peaks pre- and post-cycling was attributed to oxygen release and electrolyte salt decomposition during high-voltage cell operation [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib46" name="bbib46" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib46"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">46</span></span></a>]. Notably, the C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="double bond">O peaks of both samples appeared similar, while the intensity of the C–O peak significantly increased after cycling for the pristine NM. Turning to the F 1s spectra, we commonly observed peaks corresponding to both PVDF and NaF in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig8" name="bfig8" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig8"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>b and e. We observed peaks around 687&nbsp;eV for PVDF, the binder used. The peaks around 685&nbsp;eV for NaF were related to the formation of the SEI layer on the electrode surface [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib47" name="bbib47" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib47"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">47</span></span></a>]. This layer could be formed due to the decomposition of the electrolyte salt NaClO<sub>4</sub> and the additive FEC [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib48" name="bbib48" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib48"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">48</span></span></a>]. Then, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig8" name="bfig8" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig8"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>e showed the additional formations of NiF<sub>2</sub> and MnF<sub>2</sub> during cycling [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib49" name="bbib49" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib49"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">49</span></span></a>]. The NiF<sub>2</sub> and MnF<sub>2</sub>, a byproduct of side reactions involving HF with Ni-rich cathode materials [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib50" name="bbib50" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib50"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">50</span></span></a>], were found in lesser amounts in the NWO5@NM, compared to the pristine NM, as per our fitting results. Finally, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig8" name="bfig8" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig8"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>c and f showed the peaks related to the electrolyte salt NaClO<sub>4</sub>. The peaks at around 208.5&nbsp;eV were associated with covalently bonded Cl, a residue of NaClO<sub>4</sub> on the electrode surface. Peaks due to ionically bonded Cl appeared at around 198.5 and 200&nbsp;eV [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib50" name="bbib50" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib50"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">50</span></span></a>]. Both samples exhibited more substantial Cl<sup>−</sup> related peaks after cycling compared to before cycling. However, when considering the area ratio of the overall peaks, the Cl<sup>−</sup> peak of NWO5@NM was smaller. This indicated that the NWO5@NM electrode experienced fewer side reactions caused by the electrolyte, compared to the pristine NM. The presence of Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> at the grain boundaries was found to prevent direct contact between the electrolyte and the electrode and inhibited the electrolyte from penetrating along the grain boundaries during cycling.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig8"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324010930-gr8.jpg" height="438" alt="Fig. 8" aria-describedby="cap0045"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324010930-gr8_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324010930-gr8.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0045"><p id="fspara0045"><span class="label">Fig. 8</span>. XPS spectra of the (a) C 1s, (b) F 1s, and (c) Cl 2p taken from the surface of the NM and NWO5@NM electrodes after formation; the (d) C 1s, (e) F 1s, and (f) Cl 2p, taken from the surface of the NM and NWO5@NM electrodes after 100 cycles tests.</p></span></span></figure></div></section><section id="sec4"><h2 id="sectitle0070" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Conclusion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0170">This study presented the results of improving the grain boundaries of the polycrystalline NaNi<sub>0.8</sub>Mn<sub>0.2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> through the introduction of Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> during calcination, which led to the successful synthesis of the Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub>-infused samples without the need for any additional coating procedure. The XRD, SEM, and TEM analyses confirmed the presence of crystalline Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> in the grain boundaries of the secondary particles. Additionally, the Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub>-infused sample, with its filled voids, showed a higher bulk density. Electrochemical tests were conducted over a wide voltage range up to high voltages, and the initial charge−discharge curves at 0.1C showed that adding 5&nbsp;wt% Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> is reasonable. Subsequent tests at different temperatures confirmed that the Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> enhanced the performance of the cathode material. During cycling, Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> acted as a pathway for Na<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;ion diffusion, which was especially effective when ion movement was limited, as indicated by the CV and GITT results. Additionally, during 100 cycles at 1C, the NWO5@NM exhibited an average discharge capacity of 26.0 mAh·g<sup>−1</sup> higher than NM, with the EIS results suggesting that the Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> helped reduce the charge transfer resistance at the grain boundaries, which were charge−transfer sites. Finally, the XPS spectra of the electrodes after electrochemical evaluation showed that the Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> positively influenced the mitigation of side reactions caused by the electrolyte. This study demonstrates that strengthening the grain boundaries of the polycrystalline O3-type Ni-rich cathodes for SIBs through the introduction of Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> is a significant strategy for performance improvement, providing valuable insights into the design of high-performance batteries.</div></section><section id="sec5"><h2 id="sectitle0075" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0175"><strong>Sooin Jeong:</strong> Writing – original draft, Visualization, Formal analysis, Data curation, Conceptualization. <strong>Eunjeong Cho:</strong> Investigation. <strong>Wonchang Choi:</strong> Project administration.</div></section></div><section id="coi0010"><h2 id="sectitle0080" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of competing interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0180">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ack0010"><h2 id="sectitle0085" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgment</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0185">This research was supported by the program through the <span id="gs2">National Research Foundation of Korea</span> (<span id="gs3">NRF</span>) funded by the <span id="gs4">Ministry of Science and ICT</span> (No.<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">RS-2024-00404414</span></span></a>, Development of High Energy Density Core Materials and High-Efficiency Cell Technology for 220&nbsp;Wh/kg-Class Sodium-Ion Batteries). This research was supported by the <span id="gs5">National Research Council of Science &amp; Technology</span> (<span id="gs6">NST</span>) grant by the Korea government (<span id="gs7">MSIT</span>) (No. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs7"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">GTL24011-000</span></span></a>). This research was supported by <span id="gs8">Korea Institute for Advancement of Technology</span> (<span id="gs9">KIAT</span>) grant funded by the Korea Government (<span id="gs10">MOTIE</span>) (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs10"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">P0012748</span></span></a>, <span id="gs11">HRD</span> Program for Industrial Innovation).</div></section><div class="Appendices"><section id="appsec1"><h2 id="sectitle0090" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Appendix A. u-margin-xs-bottom">Data availability</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0035">Data will be made available on request.</div></section></div><div class="Tail"></div><div><section class="bibliography u-font-serif text-s" id="cebib0010"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">References</h2><section class="bibliography-sec" id="cebibsec0010"><ol Abraham</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans" id="ref-id-sref3">ACS Energy Lett., 5 (2020), pp. 3544-3547</div><div class="ReferenceLinks u-font-sans"><span class="link aria-describedby="ref-id-sref3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Crossref</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window"     const pendoData = {"visitor":{"pageName":"SD:product:journal:article","pageType":"CP-CA","pageProduct":"SD","pageLanguage":"en","pageEnvironment":"prod","accessType":"ae:ANON_IP","countryCode":"GB"},"account":{"id":"ae:11279","name":"ae:Imperial College London"},"events":{}};;
    pendoData.events = {
      ready: function () {
        pendo.addAltText();
      },
    };
    function runPendo(data, options) {
  const {
    firstDelay,
    maxRetries,
    urlPrefix,
    urlSuffix,
    apiKey
  } = options;
  (function (apiKey) {
    (function (p, e, n, d, o) {
      var v, w, x, y, z;
      o = p[d] = p[d] || {};
      o._q = [];
      v = ['initialize', 'identify', 'updateOptions', 'pageLoad'];
      for (w = 0, x = v.length; w < x; ++w) (function (m) {
        o[m] = o[m] || function () {
          o._q[m === v[0] ? 'unshift' : 'push']([m].concat([].slice.call(arguments, 0)));
        };
      })(v[w]);
      y = e.createElement(n);
      y.async = !0;
      y.src = urlPrefix + apiKey + urlSuffix;
      z = e.getElementsByTagName(n)[0];
      z.parentNode.insertBefore(y, z);
    })(window, document, 'script', 'pendo');
    pendo.addAltText = function () {
      var target = document.querySelector('body');
      var observer = new MutationObserver(function (mutations) {
        mutations.forEach(function (mutation) {
          if (mutation?.addedNodes?.length) {
            if (mutation.addedNodes[0]?.className?.includes("_pendo-badge")) {
              const badge = mutation.addedNodes[0];
              const altText = badge?.attributes['aria-label']?.value || 'Feedback';
              const pendoBadgeImage = pendo.dom(`#${badge?.attributes?.id.value} img`);
              if (pendoBadgeImage.length) {
                pendoBadgeImage[0]?.setAttribute('alt', altText);
              }
            }
          }
        });
      });
      var config = {
        attributeFilter: ['data-layout'],
        attributes: true,
        childList: true,
        characterData: true,
        subtree: false
      };
      observer.observe(target, config);
    };
  })(apiKey);
  (function watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay, retryAttempt) {
    if (data.visitor.id) {
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else if (typeof pageDataTracker === 'object' && typeof pageDataTracker.getVisitorId === 'function' && pageDataTracker.getVisitorId()) {
      data.visitor.id = pageDataTracker.getVisitorId();
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else {
      if (retryAttempt > 0) {
        return setTimeout(function () {
          watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay * 2, retryAttempt - 1);
        }, nextDelay);
      }
      pendo.initialize(data);
      console.debug(`gave up ... pendo initialized`);
    }
  })(firstDelay, maxRetries);
}
    window.addPendoScript = () => {
      runPendo(pendoData, {
        firstDelay: 100,
        maxRetries: 5,
        urlPrefix: 'https://cdn.pendo.io/agent/static/',
        urlSuffix: '/pendo.js',
        apiKey: 'd6c1d995-bc7e-4e53-77f1-2ea4ecbb9565',
      });
      window.addPendoScript = () => {};
    };
    addEventListener('load', () => window.addPendoScript());
  </script>
