42 2 51.86 2 64s9.86 22 22 22c6.38 0 12.12-2.76 16.14-7.12l28.64 15.38c-.5 1.84-.78 3.76-.78 5.74 0 12.14 9.86 22 22 22s22-9.86 22-22-9.86-22-22-22z"></path></svg><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Share</span></span></button></div></div></div><div class="ExportCitation u-display-inline-block" id="export-citation"><div class="popover export-citation-popover" id="export-citation-popover"><div id="popover-trigger-export-citation-popover"><button class="button-link button-link-secondary button-link-icon-left button-link-has-colored-icon" type="button" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="true"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 104 128" height="20" class="icon icon-cited-by-66"><path d="M2 58.78V106h44V64H12v-5.22C12 40.28 29.08 32 46 32V22C20.1 22 2 37.12 2 58.78zM102 32V22c-25.9 0-44 15.12-44 36.78V106h44V64H68v-5.22C68 40.28 85.08 32 102 32z"></path></svg><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Cite</span></span></button></div></div></div></div></div><div class="ArticleIdentifierLinks u-margin-xs-bottom text-xs" id="article-identifier-links"><a class="anchor doi anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jpowsour.2024.235141" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener" aria-label="Persistent link using digital object identifier" title="Persistent link using digital object identifier"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jpowsour.2024.235141</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a><a class="anchor rights-and-content anchor-primary" href="https://s100.copyright.com/AppDispatchServlet?publisherName=ELS&amp;contentID=S0378775324010930&amp;orderBeanReset=true" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Get rights and content</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div><div class="LicenseInfo text-xs u-margin-xs-bottom access-type-label-only"><div class="AccessLabel"><span class="access-indicator"></span>Full text access</div></div><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author-highlights" id="abs0020" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Highlights</h2><div id="abssec0020"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0025"><ul class="list"><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0010">Grain boundary modification enhances the performance of Ni-rich cathodes for SIBs.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0015">Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub>-infused samples are prepared by the molten salt-assisted coating method.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0020">During cycling, Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> serves as an ion diffusion channel.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0025">The introduction of Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> improves rate capability at high voltage.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0030">Grain boundary modification suppresses the side reactions with the electrolyte.</div></span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="abstract author" id="abs0010" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="abssec0010"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0010">The expansion of the battery industry and the search for alternatives to lithium–ion batteries are driving research into high-performance cathode materials for sodium–ion batteries (SIBs). The O3-type Ni-rich cathodes with high capacity are promising for use in SIBs. However, the large size of Na<sup>+</sup> ions and side reactions with electrolyte mean that they require assistance with sluggish kinetics.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0015">This work reveals a fruitful solution in the form of strengthening the grain boundaries of polycrystalline cathodes, which are vital sites of electrochemical reactions. The infusion of Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> during calcination enhances the performance of NaNi<sub>0.8</sub>Mn<sub>0.2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>, while also opening new possibilities for research into SIBs. This process facilitates Na<sup>+</sup> ion diffusion during cycling and suppresses undesirable side reactions, thereby significantly increasing the reversible capacity of NaNi<sub>0.8</sub>Mn<sub>0.2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>. The exceptional rate capability of Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub>-infused NaNi<sub>0.8</sub>Mn<sub>0.2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>, even at high current densities and low operating temperatures, instills a sense of optimism regarding the potential of grain boundary modification to improve performance for SIBs.</div></div></div><div class="abstract graphical" id="abs0015"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Graphical abstract</h2><div id="abssec0015"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0020"><span class="display"><figure class="figure text-xs" id="undfig1"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324010930-ga1.jpg" height="200" alt="Image 1"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324010930-ga1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (357KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (357KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324010930-ga1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span></figure></span></div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S0378775324010541"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S0378775324010991"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="kwrds0010" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="kwrd0010" class="keyword"><span>Sodium–ion battery</span></div><div id="kwrd0015" class="keyword"><span>O3-type layered cathode</span></div><div id="kwrd0020" class="keyword"><span>Ni-rich material</span></div><div id="kwrd0025" class="keyword"><span>Grain boundary modification</span></div><div id="kwrd0030" class="keyword"><span>Molten salt-assisted</span></div><div id="kwrd0035" class="keyword"><span>High-performance</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="sec1"><h2 id="sectitle0035" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0040">As various industries undergo electrification, the demand for electricity continues to surge, necessitating the use of energy storage devices for efficient energy management [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib1" name="bbib1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">1</span></span></a>]. This underscores the need for the development of cost-effective and high-efficiency technologies, such as lithium–ion batteries (LIBs). While LIBs have been the frontrunners in the battery market, concerns over unstable resource supply have followed [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib2" name="bbib2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2</span></span></a>]. Thus, sodium–ion batteries (SIBs) have emerged as a promising alternative [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib3" name="bbib3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">3</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0045">The SIB, which operates similarly to the LIB, offers several advantages, including its cost-effectiveness, abundance of resources, and safety, due to a lower risk of thermal runaway from short circuits [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib4" name="bbib4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">4</span></span></a>]. However, to be established as the next generation of energy storage devices, SIBs require further improvements in volumetric and gravimetric energy density, as well as cyclability [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib5" name="bbib5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">5</span></span></a>]. Advances in cathode materials, which act as the source of carrier ions (Na<sup>+</sup>), are crucial for battery performance. Cathode materials for SIBs include layered transition metal oxides, polyanionic compounds, and Prussian blue and its analogs [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib6" name="bbib6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">6</span></span></a>]. Among these, sodium-layered transition metal oxides (Na<sub>x</sub>TMO<sub>2</sub>) stand out as promising high-performance materials due to their high theoretical capacity, average working voltage, and facile synthesis [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib7" name="bbib7" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib7"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">7</span></span></a>]. Additionally, they can utilize manufacturing processes and technologies from LIBs, making them the most commercially viable among cathode materials for SIBs [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib8" name="bbib8" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib8"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">8</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0050">Many transition metals with redox activity in SIBs, such as Ni, Cr, Fe, Co, Cu, and Mn, are present. Among these, Ni contributes to most of the charge compensation through multiple redox reactions, enabling the development of high-capacity cathode materials [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib9" name="bbib9" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib9"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">9</span></span></a>]. However, NaNiO<sub>2</sub> suffers from reduced overall electrochemical performance due to its low stability. This has led to research exploring the partial substitution of Ni with Mn to enhance material stability, as Mn<sup>4+</sup> is electrochemically inactive and helps stabilize the crystal structure [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib10" name="bbib10" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib10"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">10</span></span></a>]. Additionally, sodium-layered oxides are generally classified into types, such as P2 and O3, depending on the coordination environment of Na<sup>+</sup> and the stacking sequence of oxygen layers, with each type exhibiting different characteristics. The O3-type sodium layered oxides typically have a high Na content of around 0.8–1, making them more suitable for high-capacity cathode materials [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib11" name="bbib11" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib11"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">11</span></span></a>]. Therefore, the O3-type NaNi<sub>0.8</sub>Mn<sub>0.2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>, with high contents of Na and Ni, is expected to have high capacity. However, O3-type sodium layered oxides have persistent issues, such as miserable rate capability due to the slow Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion kinetics, and poor cycling performance due to the side reactions between the electrode and electrolyte. Cycling at high voltage further aggravates these problems [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib12" name="bbib12" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib12"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">12</span></span></a>]. These challenges present exciting opportunities for further research in the field of SIBs.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0055">The surface of the cathode material interacts directly with the electrolyte, and serves as a site for charge transfer reactions, making it a critical factor to enhance the performance of cathode materials [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib13" name="bbib13" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib13"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">13</span></span></a>]. Numerous studies have demonstrated that surface modification through coating is a rational strategy to optimize materials at a fundamental level [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib14" name="bbib14" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib14"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">14</span></span></a>]. For example, coating materials with high chemical stability, such as MnPO<sub>4</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib15" name="bbib15" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib15"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">15</span></span></a>], Na<sub>3</sub>Zr<sub>2</sub>SiPO<sub>12</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib16" name="bbib16" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib16"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">16</span></span></a>], and Na<sub>3</sub>PO<sub>4</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib17" name="bbib17" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib17"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">17</span></span></a>], alleviated performance degradation issues caused by side reactions on the cathode surface. There were also cases where the improvement in ionic conductivity of the material enhanced the reversibility of electrochemical reactions. Ion conductors, such as NaTi<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib18" name="bbib18" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib18"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">18</span></span></a>], Li<sub>2</sub>SiO<sub>3</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib19" name="bbib19" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib19"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">19</span></span></a>], and Na<sub>2</sub>SiO<sub>3</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib20" name="bbib20" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib20"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">20</span></span></a>], were adopted as coating materials.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0060">In this context, grain boundary engineering is desirable. Grain boundaries are regions where two grains meet, and more specifically, are interfacial defects between the primary particles of the cathode material [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib21" name="bbib21" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib21"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21</span></span></a>]. The grain boundaries in polycrystalline cathode materials serve as local spaces for carrier ion diffusion, due to the low activation energy of the grain boundaries [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib22" name="bbib22" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib22"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">22</span></span></a>]. Carrier ions diffuse while overcoming the energy barriers of the grain boundaries. Therefore, the characteristics of the grain boundaries in the cathode material directly affect ion diffusion, which in turn impacts the rate capability and power density of the battery. Modifying the grain boundaries through coating can provide ion diffusion channels, potentially reducing ion transport resistance and increasing ion diffusivity. Additionally, it can suppress side reactions with the electrolyte and prevent liquid electrolyte infiltration during cycling [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib23" name="bbib23" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib23"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">23</span></span></a>]. In previous studies, He et al. reported on the Li-rich Mn-based layered cathode material for LIBs by adopting near-zero-strain LiAlO<sub>2</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib24" name="bbib24" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib24"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">24</span></span></a>], utilizing the reactive infiltration method (RIM) to form a uniform coating layer, and infusing it into the grain boundaries of Li<sub>1.2</sub>Mn<sub>0.54</sub>Ni<sub>0.26</sub>O<sub>2</sub> through a sintering step. This study demonstrated that LiAlO<sub>2</sub> present at the grain boundaries formed a coherent interface with the host materials, enabling the battery to achieve high performance. Additionally, Wang et al. proposed a method to inject SeO<sub>2</sub> into the grain boundaries of Li-rich layered cathode materials by utilizing the high selenophilic properties of transition metal atoms [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib25" name="bbib25" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib25"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">25</span></span></a>]. They formed robust interfacial structures by melting the SeO<sub>2</sub> distributed in the grain boundaries, resulting in polycrystalline Li<sub>1.2</sub>Mn<sub>0.54</sub>Ni<sub>0.13</sub>Co<sub>0.13</sub>O<sub>2</sub> with excellent rate capability and cycling stability. Research on various grain boundary modifications continues, with additional examples including LiMn<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub>-modified Li<sub>0.6</sub>Co<sub>0.2</sub>Mn<sub>0.2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib26" name="bbib26" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib26"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">26</span></span></a>], and ZrV<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub>-coated LiNi<sub>0.8</sub>Co<sub>0.1</sub>Mn<sub>0.1</sub>O<sub>2</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib27" name="bbib27" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib27"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">27</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0065">Herein, we introduce Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> to modify the grain boundaries of O3-type Ni-rich NaNi<sub>0.8</sub>Mn<sub>0.2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>. Tungsten compounds are transition metal oxides that are used for various purposes, and are employed in many battery studies [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib28" name="bbib28" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib28"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">28</span></span></a>]. Sodium tungstate, Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub>, has a normal spinel-type structure, and a cubic phase with space group Fd–3m [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib29" name="bbib29" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib29"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">29</span></span></a>]. It is thermodynamically stable, and exhibits excellent electrical conductivity [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib30" name="bbib30" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib30"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">30</span></span></a>]. Notably, Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> has a melting point of 698&nbsp;°C [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib31" name="bbib31" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib31"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">31</span></span></a>], which is lower than the calcination temperature set for material synthesis. Based on this, we anticipate that mixing Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> with other starting materials and calcining them will cause it to melt along the grain boundaries of the NaNi<sub>0.8</sub>Mn<sub>0.2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>, infusing between the primary particles. This strategy provides a processing advantage, as it does not require additional steps for grain boundary modification.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0070">We expect that the Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> at the grain boundaries of NaNi<sub>0.8</sub>Mn<sub>0.2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> will form a network that enhances Na<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;ion mobility during cycling, solving the inherent ionic conductivity issues of O3-type sodium layered cathodes. Additionally, the Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> will prevent particles from directly contacting the electrolyte, thereby suppressing side reactions with the electrolyte. Consequently, we demonstrate that the Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub>-infused NaNi<sub>0.8</sub>Mn<sub>0.2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> is the O3-type Ni-rich cathode for high-performance with improved ionic conductivity. To validate this, we conduct material property analyses and electrochemical tests under various conditions to assess the effects of Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub>, and the feasibility of grain boundary engineering. This work aims to contribute to research for SIBs as a case study for designing high-performance batteries through the grain boundary engineering of electrode materials.</div></section><section id="sec2"><h2 id="sectitle0040" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Experimental section</h2><section id="sec2.1"><h3 id="sectitle0045" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.1. Synthesis of the Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub>-infused NaNi<sub>0.8</sub>Mn<sub>0.2</sub>O<sub>2</sub></h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0075">We prepared a powder mixture of precursor 8.143&nbsp;g Ni<sub>0.8</sub>Mn<sub>0.2</sub>(OH)<sub>2</sub> (POSCO HOLDINGS CO., Ltd., Korea) and 3.915&nbsp;g NaOH (reagent grade, ≥98 %, pellets, Sigma–Aldrich) as the Na source in a 1:1.05&nbsp;M ratio in a controlled humidity condition. Then, we added Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> (99.995 % trace metals basis, Sigma–Aldrich) as the coating material to the mixture in amounts corresponding to 3, 5, and 7&nbsp;wt% of NaNi<sub>0.8</sub>Mn<sub>0.2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>. The powder was mixed for 20&nbsp;min to ensure complete mixing and then placed in an alumina crucible for calcination. The calcination was conducted in an O<sub>2</sub> atmosphere at 700&nbsp;°C for 12&nbsp;h, followed by natural cooling in the furnace. The obtained samples were named NWO3@NM, NWO5@NM, and NWO7@NM, respectively, depending on the amount of Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> added.</div></section><section id="sec2.2"><h3 id="sectitle0050" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.2. Synthesis of the pristine NaNi<sub>0.8</sub>Mn<sub>0.2</sub>O<sub>2</sub></h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0080">To verify performance enhancement, we synthesized the pristine NaNi<sub>0.8</sub>Mn<sub>0.2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> using only precursor 8.143&nbsp;g Ni<sub>0.8</sub>Mn<sub>0.2</sub>(OH)<sub>2</sub> and 3.915&nbsp;g NaOH. This sample, named NM, was obtained following the same experimental procedure as described above.</div></section><section id="sec2.3"><h3 id="sectitle0055" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.3. Material characterization</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0085">Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometric (ICP−OES, Agilent 5110) analysis was conducted to quantitatively measure the concentration of metallic elements. All samples were pre-treated with hydrofluoric acid to detect tungsten. X-ray diffraction (XRD, Rigaku Smartlab) analysis was performed using Cu–Kα radiation as the X-ray source, in the 2θ range 10–80°, with a step size of 0.02° and a scan rate of 1°·min<sup>−1</sup>. The FullProf Suite program was adopted for Rietveld refinement of the obtained diffraction patterns. To obtain surface information, we acquired images using field emission–scanning electron microscopy (FE–SEM, Hitachi High–Tech SU8010). For cross-sectional analysis of the samples, specimens for spherical aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy (Cs–STEM, JEOL NEOARM) were prepared using a focused ion beam system (FIB, Carl Zeiss Crossbeam 350). Concurrently with Cs–STEM, energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping was conducted. The bulk density of the samples was measured using powder resistivity measurement (HANTECH HPRM–FA2) in the pressure range 0–2000 kgf. Finally, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific K–Alpha) analysis was performed to obtain the surface elemental spectra of the electrodes.</div></section><section id="sec2.4"><h3 id="sectitle0060" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.4. Cell assembly and electrochemical measurements</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0090">Half-cells of SIBs were prepared using CR−2032 coin cell parts (Wellcos Corporation). The cathode slurry was composed of 80&nbsp;wt% active material, 10&nbsp;wt% Super P, and 10&nbsp;wt% polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF), all dispersed in N–methyl pyrrolidone (NMP). The working electrode was obtained by coating a slurry on Al foil (15&nbsp;μm) to a consistent thickness of 100&nbsp;μm, and then drying it in a vacuum oven at 80&nbsp;°C for 12&nbsp;h, and it was punched into a circle shape with a diameter of 12&nbsp;mm. The active mass loading level of all working electrodes for testing was confirmed to 2.8–3.2&nbsp;mg·cm<sup>−2</sup>. The Na metal (cubes, containing mineral oil, 99.9 % trace metals basis, Sigma–Aldrich) was used as the reference electrode, and a glass fiber filter (0.42&nbsp;mm, Whatman GF/F) was employed as the separator. Additionally, the electrolyte used was 1&nbsp;M NaClO<sub>4</sub> (ACS reagent, ≥99.0 %, Sigma–Aldrich) in a solvent mixture of ethylene carbonate (EC), propylene carbonate (PC), and diethyl carbonate (DEC) in the vol% ratios 1:1:1, together with 5&nbsp;wt% fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC). Cell fabrication was carried out in an Ar-filled glove box.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0095">Cycling tests were performed using a battery test system (WonATech WBCS 3000) in the voltage range 1.5–4.1&nbsp;V (<em>vs</em>. Na/Na<sup>+</sup>). The theoretical capacity of all samples was 200 mAh·g<sup><strong>−</strong>1</sup>. Under the same conditions, the cyclic voltammetry (CV) was measured, and the galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) was conducted by applying the constant current of 0.1C for 10&nbsp;min, followed by the 30&nbsp;min rest period. To evaluate the rate capability, the current density and operating temperature were varied. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was conducted using a potentiostat (Biologic SP–300) by using the 5&nbsp;mV amplitude signal in the frequency range of 100&nbsp;μHz to 1&nbsp;MHz.</div></section></section><section id="sec3"><h2 id="sectitle0065" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Results and discussion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0100">The polycrystalline cathode is a secondary particle formed by the aggregation of multiple primary particles [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib32" name="bbib32" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib32"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">32</span></span></a>]. Therefore, primary particles, grain boundaries, voids, etc., can be observed in the cross-section of the O3-type Ni-rich NaNi<sub>0.8</sub>Mn<sub>0.2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib33" name="bbib33" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib33"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">33</span></span></a>]. Since grain boundaries are sites where various reactions occur during cycling [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib22" name="bbib22" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib22"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">22</span></span></a>], we focused on the low melting point of Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub>, which has excellent electrical conductivity [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib30" name="bbib30" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib30"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">30</span></span></a>], and attempted to modify grain boundaries. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a> shows the cross-section of the O3-type Ni-rich cathode and the effect of grain boundary modification due to the introduction of Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub>. The cross-section of secondary particles is depicted with reference to the FIB−SEM images (discussed later), which provide detailed views of the grain boundaries and the distribution of Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub>. The melted Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> during calcination will flow between the primary particles, and when completely cooled, remain in the existing grain boundaries and voids. It is expected that the material existing in the grain boundaries of the Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub>-infused particles will assist in improving the rate capability of the cathode material by acting as a diffusion channel for carrier ions and helping the movement of electrons [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib34" name="bbib34" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib34"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">34</span></span></a>]. In addition, it is anticipated that the pathway for electrolyte penetration will be blocked during cycling to prevent side reactions with the electrolyte, leading to additional performance improvement [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib35" name="bbib35" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib35"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">35</span></span></a>].</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig1"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324010930-gr1.jpg" height="361" alt="Fig. 1" aria-describedby="cap0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324010930-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (691KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (691KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324010930-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0010"><p id="fspara0010"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. Schematic depicting the effect of grain boundary modification by introducing Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub>.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0105"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S1</span></span></a> shows the ICP−OES analysis results for quantitative measurement of the elemental composition and the Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> content of all samples. The pristine NM indicated molar ratios of Na:Ni:Mn of 1.050:0.798:0.202, which were close to the theoretical composition of 1.0:0.8:0.2, and these consistent results were also observed in the Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub>-infused samples. The concentration of tungsten was used as the basis for the calculation to determine the Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> content in the NWO3@NM, NWO5@NM, and NWO7@NM. We assumed that the Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> did not undergo compositional changes due to calcination, and later ensured the validity of this assumption through XRD analysis. The respective Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> contents were found to be 3.391, 5.116, and 7.247&nbsp;wt%, indicating that approximately 3, 5, and 7&nbsp;wt%, respectively, of Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> was included in each material, as inferred from the experimental process.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0110">We analyzed the crystal structures and impurity phases of all samples using XRD analysis and Rietveld refinement. To gain more accurate understanding of the crystal structure of Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub>, we temporarily added excess NWO15@NM. The synthesis method, replicated for preparation, has consistently yielded reliable results. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a> shows that the diffraction peaks of all samples, particularly at 17, 34, 35, 37, and 42°, unequivocally signify the successful synthesis of the O3-type layered cathode material [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib36" name="bbib36" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib36"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">36</span></span></a>]. In the samples infused with Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub>, the diffraction peaks corresponding to Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> with the cubic spinel structure (space group: Fd–3m) were discerned [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib29" name="bbib29" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib29"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">29</span></span></a>]. As expected, more pronounced diffraction patterns were observed in the NWO15@NM. This analysis substantiated the assertion that there was no alteration in the crystal structure and composition of the Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> during calcination. In other Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub>-infused samples, the inversion of the (003) and (104) peak intensities, compared to the pristine NM, also served as a confirmation. Furthermore, the XRD data also seemed to exhibit a diffraction pattern corresponding to Na<sub>3</sub>MnO<sub>4</sub> (space group: <em>P</em>2<sub>1</sub>3). Na<sub>3</sub>MnO<sub>4</sub> is known to be formed around 700&nbsp;°C, and some of these sodium manganese oxides were synthesized [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib37" name="bbib37" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib37"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">37</span></span></a>]. Using the FullProf Suite, Rietveld refinement was performed to investigate the multiple phases and lattice parameters of each sample. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1</span></span></a> and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S2</span></span></a> present the results. The XRD data allowed the diffraction patterns of the O3-type NaNi<sub>0.8</sub>Mn<sub>0.2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>, Na<sub>3</sub>MnO<sub>4</sub>, and Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> phases to be precisely identified, which patterns were crucial to understand the material's properties. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S2</span></span></a> shows that as the content of Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> increases, the lattice volume of the unit cell gradually increased. This was because Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> has a relatively large cell volume [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib29" name="bbib29" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib29"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">29</span></span></a>].</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig2"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324010930-gr2.jpg" height="290" alt="Fig. 2" aria-describedby="cap0015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324010930-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (707KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (707KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324010930-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0015"><p id="fspara0015"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. XRD patterns of the NM, NWO3@NM, NWO5@NM, NWO7@NM, and NWO15@NM samples.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0115"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>a−d and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2</span></span></a> present the FE−SEM images, where we scrutinized the morphology and particle size of the secondary particles in each sample. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>a−d revealed that all samples were comprised of spherical particles with diameters of approximately 10&nbsp;μm, a finding that held for both the pristine NM and the Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub>-infused samples. Moreover, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2</span></span></a>, the high-magnification FE−SEM images, were instrumental in confirming the successful infusion of Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub>. In the case of the pristine NM, gaps between the primary particles were observable (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2a</span></span></a>), whereas in the others, these gaps were absent (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2b</span></span></a>−d). Additionally, to analyze the cross-sections of the secondary particles in some samples, we used FIB processing. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S3</span></span></a>, the NWO5@NM appeared to be more densely packed, compared to the pristine NM. These findings provided additional evidence for the successful infusion of the Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub>, as planned.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig3"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324010930-gr3.jpg" height="631" alt="Fig. 3" aria-describedby="cap0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324010930-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (2MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (2MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324010930-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0020"><p id="fspara0020"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. FE−SEM imagery of the (a) NM, (b) NWO3@NM, (c) NWO5@NM, and (d) NWO7@NM; Cs−STEM analysis results of the NWO5@NM, (e) and (g) HAADF images, (f) and (h) elemental EDS mapping images of the Na (yellow), Ni (blue), Mn (purple), W (red), and O (green), and (i) the EDS line scan taken across the grain boundary. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0120">Subsequently, we utilized Cs–STEM technology to further investigate the cross-sections of the NM and NWO5@NM samples that were pretreated with FIB, focusing mainly on the grain boundaries. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>e–i are key parts of our study, providing visual evidence of grain boundary modification resulting from Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> infusion. Firstly, the HAADF image of NWO5@NM closely resembled the FIB–SEM results (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>e), as did the pristine NM (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S4a</span></span></a>). Additionally, the elemental EDS mapping of the cross-sections revealed by FIB indicated a uniform distribution of Na, Ni, Mn, and O elements in both samples (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>f, and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S4b</span></span></a>). However, in the NWO5@NM, W was prominently concentrated on the surfaces and grain boundaries of the secondary particles. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>g is the high-magnification HAADF image where grain boundaries are clearly visible, and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>h is the EDS mapping image to identify the presence of W at the grain boundaries. These images demonstrated that W was specifically concentrated at the grain boundaries. Additionally, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>i is the EDS line scanning curve along the A–B section in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>g, and we observed a sharp increase in W concentration in the grain boundaries (marked as 'GB') once again. The Cs–STEM analysis confirmed that Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> was successfully distributed at the grain boundaries, suggesting that grain boundary modification could potentially enhance the electrochemical performance of the material.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0125"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S5</span></span></a> illustrates the comprehensive alterations in sample properties attributed to the presence of Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> at the grain boundaries. We conducted measurements on the bulk density of the 3.5&nbsp;g pristine NM and 3.6&nbsp;g NWO5@NM samples under applied pressure. In both cases, the bulk density values increased in proportion to the intensity of the applied pressure. However, the NWO5@NM consistently exhibited higher bulk density values than the pristine NM, with the difference between the initial and final values being approximately 0.46 and 0.41&nbsp;g·cc<sup>−1</sup> for the pristine NM and NWO5@NM, respectively. This suggested that the molten Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> filled the voids within the secondary particles, leading to a minor change in the NWO5@NM. Thus, the densely packed primary particles of the NWO5@NM were expected to be more resistant to electrolyte penetration, compared to the pristine NM, potentially preventing side reactions caused by electrolyte penetration during cycling, and contributing to performance improvement [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib23" name="bbib23" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib23"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">23</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib38" name="bbib38" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib38"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">38</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib39" name="bbib39" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib39"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">39</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0130">Our investigation into the impact of Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> for grain boundary modification on electrochemical performance had practical implications for this study. Cycling tests were conducted in the voltage range of 1.5–4.1&nbsp;V (<em>vs.</em> Na/Na<sup>+</sup>) at room temperature (25&nbsp;°C), and as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>a, the initial specific discharge capacities of the NM, NWO3@NM, NWO5@NM, and NWO7@NM electrodes were 205.1, 196.0, 195.8, and 194.6 mAh·g<sup>−1</sup>, respectively. In the first cycle of all samples, the Coulombic efficiencies were similar, approximately more than 90 %. The initial specific capacities of the Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub>-infused samples were lower than that of the pristine NM, due to the reduced capacity caused by the Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub>, which did not directly participate in the electrochemical reactions. This suggested that adding approximately 5&nbsp;wt% of Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> would be the most reasonable strategy.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig4"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324010930-gr4.jpg" height="527" alt="Fig. 4" aria-describedby="cap0025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324010930-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1008KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1008KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324010930-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0025"><p id="fspara0025"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. Electrochemical performance at room temperature (25&nbsp;°C); (a) first charge–discharge curves at 0.1C, (b) discharge capacities, and (c) discharge profiles of rate-dependent cycling performance at various current densities of the NM, NWO3@NM, NWO5@NM, and NWO7@NM.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0135">We also conducted the cycling test at various current densities within the same voltage range 1.5–4.1&nbsp;V (<em>vs.</em> Na/Na<sup>+</sup>), changing the current density continuously every 3 cycles. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>b shows that the average discharge capacity for the initial cycles of the pristine NM was superior. However, during cycling, a significant capacity decline of NM was observed, compared to the Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub>-infused samples. In contrast, the NWO5@NM and NWO7@NM showed superior discharge capacity starting from 0.2C, with this advantage becoming more pronounced at 0.5C. Except for the cycles corresponding to the formation, the Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub>-infused samples showed better performance in almost all sections; and among them, the NWO5@NM provided the best results. The data for the last 3 cycles at 0.1C to evaluate the capacity reversibility suggested that the grain boundary-modified samples provided better performance than did the pristine NM. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>c provides the discharge profiles at each current density during cycling. As anticipated, the Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub>-infused samples maintained the initial charge–discharge profile better than the pristine NM, generally displaying higher energy density.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0140">We performed additional electrochemical tests to assess the rate capability, focusing exclusively on the pristine NM and NWO5@NM samples. All subsequent tests were performed after 3 cycles at 0.1C, representing the formation process. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig5" name="bfig5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>a and b display the CV curves of the NM and NWO5@NM, respectively, at scan rates of 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, and 0.8&nbsp;mV·s<sup>−1</sup>. Multiple peaks resulting from the redox reactions of Ni can be observed within the voltage range of 2.0–4.0&nbsp;V (<em>vs.</em> Na/Na<sup>+</sup>) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib38" name="bbib38" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib38"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">38</span></span></a>]. We evaluated that the NWO5@NM exhibited superior reaction reversibility compared to the NM, based on the shape, intensity, and symmetry of all peaks observed during the charge and discharge processes [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib40" name="bbib40" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib40"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">40</span></span></a>]. To explain the enhancement of rate capability, we employed the Randles−Sevcik equation to calculate the apparent Na<sup>+</sup> ion diffusion coefficient (<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-1-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>D</mi><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>N</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>a</mi></mrow><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo></msup></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="5.554ex" height="2.432ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 2391.1 1047.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.697ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-44"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(828,-239)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-4E"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(628,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-61"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1002,290)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">N</mi><mi is="true">a</mi></mrow><mo is="true">+</mo></msup></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-1"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">N</mi><mi is="true">a</mi></mrow><mo is="true">+</mo></msup></msub></mrow></math></script></span>), and assumed that the reactions occurring during cycling involve reversible electron transfer processes at 298&nbsp;K [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib41" name="bbib41" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib41"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">41</span></span></a>]. This was done using the data from the four peaks observed during the charging (O1, O2) and discharging (R1, R2) in each CV curve. The following equation is the Randles−Sevcik equation rearranged for <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-2-Frame" height="5.086ex" viewBox="0 -1442.7 12098.6 2189.9" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -1.735ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-44"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(828,-239)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use id="MathJax-Element-4"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">n</mi></mrow></math></script></span> is the total number of electrons per mole in the electrochemical reaction, <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-5-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">F</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-5"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">F</mi></mrow></math></script></span> is the Faraday constant (96,485&nbsp;C·mol<sup>−1</sup>), <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-6-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>A</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.743ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 750.5 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true">A</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-6"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">A</mi></mrow></math></script></span> is the working electrode area (1.131&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup>), <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-7-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>C</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">C</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-7"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">C</mi></mrow></math></script></span> is the Na<sup>+</sup> ion concentration of the electrode, <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-8-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>R</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.764ex" height="1.971ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 759.5 848.5" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-52"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">R</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-8"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">R</mi></mrow></math></script></span> is the gas constant (8.314&nbsp;J·mol<sup>−1</sup>·K<sup>−1</sup>), and <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-9-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi height="1.971ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 704.5 848.5" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-54"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">T</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-9"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">T</mi></mrow></math></script></span> is the operating temperature (298&nbsp;K). <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig5" name="bfig5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>c and d show the relationship between the peak currents (O1, O2, R1, and R2) and the square root of the scan rate for each sample. We considered this relationship to be a linear equation, and fitted it to obtain the slope values, then substituted it into Eq. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fd1" name="bfd1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fd1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">(1)</span></span></a> to calculate <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-10-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>D</mi><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>N</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>a</mi></mrow><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo></msup></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="5.554ex" height="2.432ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 2391.1 1047.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.697ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-44"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(828,-239)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-4E"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(628,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-61"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1002,290)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">N</mi><mi is="true">a</mi></mrow><mo is="true">+</mo></msup></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-10"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">N</mi><mi is="true">a</mi></mrow><mo is="true">+</mo></msup></msub></mrow></math></script></span> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib42" name="bbib42" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib42"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">42</span></span></a>]. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig5" name="bfig5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>e, and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S3</span></span></a>, the diffusion coefficient varied with the voltage. From the calculated values, we concluded that the NWO5@NM facilitated easier ion diffusion during cycling, and that the Na<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>4</sub> might have acted as an ion diffusion channel. However, the electrochemical reactions in the battery do not solely depend on the diffusion of carrier ions. Both diffusion-controlled current (Faradaic) and capacitive current (non-Faradaic) occur continuously, with their respective contributions varying with voltage [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib41" name="bbib41" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib41"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">41</span></span></a>]. By applying the following equation, which illustrates the relationship between current and scan rate, we derived the <em>b</em> value corresponding to the sum of the two types of currents:<span class="display"><span id="fd2" class="formula"><span class="label">(2)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-11-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>log</mi><mspace width=&quot;0.25em&quot; is=&quot;true&quot; style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="23.942ex" height="2.663ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 10308.2 1146.6" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.812ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-69"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(345,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-70"></use></g></g><g is="true" is="true"></mspace><mi is="true">v</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-11"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">log</mi><mspace width="0.25em" is="true"></mspace><msub is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mi is="true">p</mi></msub><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">=</mo><mi is="true">log</mi><mspace width="0.25em" is="true"></mspace><mi
